Description: Rim sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery column-krater with root of handle-plate; interior: glazed black with added red band just below rim; on top of rim, chain of incised lotuses (with added red on calyxes) and palmettes (with red on cuffs) alternately reversed; on handle-plate head of cock (with red on comb and wattle) to right; on vertical face of lip, stepped zigzags; neck black (fired red in places).
Curator's comments: For parallels regarding the chains of lotuses and palmettes and step zigzags, see Amyx 1988, pl. 117, 1a and b (Late Corinthian); see also Newhall Stillwell, A. and Benson, J. L., Corinth: Results of Excavations Conducted by the American School of Classical Studies at Athens XV.3: The Potters Quarter - The Pottery. Princeton 1984, pl. 30, fig. 660; CVA Cleveland, Museum of Art 2, no. 21-22, pl. (1803-1804) 57.1-2, 58.1-4.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 104, no. A158)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 220, no. 56)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.037) (Phase 1)
